quote: What are you doing here?
That's a stupid question.
Where'd you get these uniforms?
That's a stupid question, too.
Please excuse the doctor, sir. He just woke up.
Nog, these people are not Starfleet officers.
They're not?
(letting him in on the secret) We're mutants.
Genetically engineered mutants -- (showing off her figure) Can't you tell?
Does anyone at the Institute know you're missing?
That's a stupid --
Will you stop saying that!
Why are you so upset? (crossing to the examining room) You wanted Sarina brought here, well, here she is!
I was considering bringing her here for treatment -- when I was ready. I need to modify my surgical equipment before I can do the procedure.
Don't worry, we'll help. When we're through with Sarina, she'll be just like us.
Do you have any idea how much trouble you could get into for impersonating Starfleet officers?
Jack, you didn't say anything about us getting in trouble...
We didn't get caught, did we?
Didn't anyone question you?
Of course. But when they did, Patrick would just say...
That's a stupid question...
You'd be surprised how well it works.
I'll say.
What are they going to do to us... ?
It's all right... I'll straighten this out somehow.
Hello, Sarina.
Do you remember me... ?
Of course she remembers you. She's not an idiot.
She's just a little cataleptic.
Are you really going to be able to make her better... ?
I'm going to do my best.
That's a promise...
They posed as an admiral and his staff. If you want me to convince Starfleet not to press charges, you're going to have to give me a damn good reason.
Sir, they just wanted to bring Sarina here so I could help her. They meant well.
They meant well? That's the same excuse you used when they were caught trying to pass military secrets to the Dominion.
They were only trying to save lives by shortening the war and --

Doctor, I appreciate that you feel a connection with them because you're genetically engineered yourself -- but they have displayed a consistent disregard for the rules that the rest of society lives by.
Maybe that's because they're not allowed to live in society.
We are not here to debate Federation policy toward the genetically enhanced. We are here to discuss what to do with these people now that they're aboard.
Of course. With your permission, I'd like to proceed with Sarina's treatment.
I take it the Institute has given you approval to move forward?
A copy of the medical protocols I submitted. Doctor Loews, Sarina's legal guardian, has given her consent.
(nods, studies the PADD) I see this procedure's never been tried on anyone before.
There's no guarantee that it'll work, but if it does, it could change everything for her.

There's no reason to think she has the same type of behavioral disorders as Jack and the others. Her problem is that she's trapped inside her own mind. This procedure could free her. There are a few technical issues that have to be dealt with before I operate, but I'm confident they can be ironed out.
You've put a lot of time into this, haven't you?
I owe it to her. I could've ended up like Sarina, but I was lucky -- my DNA re-sequencing didn't have any unintended side effects.
All right, doctor. I'll take care of Starfleet, you take care of Sarina.
Thank you, captain.
I'll arrange for the rest of them to be sent back to the Institute.
Actually, sir, I was hoping you'd be willing to let them stay on for a while.
For what reason?
Sarina's spent the last fifteen years with them. If the procedure works and she starts to come out of her isolation, having familiar faces around will be helpful.
We'll set up quarters for them in one of the cargo bays.
I appreciate it, sir.
Just make sure they stay there. I don't want them getting out and causing trouble like they did last time.
I'll see that it doesn't happen again.
I'm going to hold you to that.
And one more thing... get them out of those uniforms.
There. Don't you look pretty?
Here?
A little to the left.
What difference does it make?
This isn't where it was last time.
He's right.
Fine. (moving the couch an inch) How's that?
Much better.
Well, well? What did the captain say?
All systems go.
See? See? I told you it was a good idea to bring her here.
That's right, Jack. I remember.
So when do we operate?
We?
You're going to need help.
Oh, so you're a surgeon now?
How hard can it be?
Thanks for the offer, but...
Oh, I get it! You want to take all the credit!
It's not about credit, it's about what's best for Sarina.
Fine. I'm busy anyway.
New project.
Glad to hear it. What are you working on?
Wouldn't you like to know?
Well, I'll leave you to it then. Just do me one favor, change out of those uniforms.
(crouching by Sarina's chair) Sarina? I'd like to take you to the Infirmary to run some tests. Is that all right?
She's afraid it's going to hurt.
It won't. I promise.
You're in good hands. Very good hands.
Don't get your hopes up, Julian. It's over between us. I've got a new man in my life right now. That gorgeous little Ferengi...
Nog?
Jealous? That's sweet.
Hurry back...

Sarina's cerebral cortex was genetically enhanced in order to accelerate the rate at which she processes information. The problem is, her visual and auditory systems aren't able to channel stimuli into her cortex fast enough. Because they're out of sync, she can't focus on what's going on around her.
Is there any way to get her sensory processes up to speed?
I need to stimulate the growth of new synapses in her thalamus.
Which means I have to be able to manipulate neural proteins at the subatomic level.
Then you've got a problem. This is the most advanced
Now you know why I asked you to come down here.
I wish I could help you, Julian, but at resolutions that small, quantum fluctuations become impossible to control. There's nothing I can do to make this thing any more accurate.
How can you say that? You haven't even tried yet.
I'm telling you it can't be done.
I'm sorry.
Sorry isn't good enough, Miles! This is Sarina's only chance to live a normal life.
I can't break the laws of physics. No one can.
Psst. Psst.
Your friend was right, you can't break the laws of physics...
But you can bend them!

(showing off their contraption) We recalibrated the imaging diodes. It's so accurate, you could clip the wings of an angel dancing on the head of a pin. (embarrassed by his little flight of fancy) If you wanted to.
Anything?
Sarina?
How am I supposed to know you understand me if you don't give me some sign... anything... it doesn't matter how small...
It's been five days, and she's as unresponsive as she was before the procedure.
I know you're disappointed, Julian, but you did everything you could.
Well it wasn't enough.

I'm sorry. Obviously you want to punish yourself. Do you want help? I'm really good at punishing myself. Let's see. If I were you, I'd be kicking myself for making promises I couldn't keep. For getting everyone's hopes up. For being arrogant enough to think that I could help Sarina when dozens of other doctors have failed. Should I keep going?
No, that pretty much covers it. Thanks.
Glad I could help.
What is it?
I'm not sure.
Sarina... What are you looking at?
(looking around in fascination) Everything...
You heard me...
(trying to make sense of it) I thought something... and you heard it.
You spoke, Sarina...
Over here, Sarina. I want to check something.
What is it?
Listen.
It's nice.
You're right. I never really noticed before.
Hmm... this is a little odd. Her norepinephrine levels are slightly elevated.
What's causing it?
I'm not sure.
It's probably due to limbic overcompensation. The levels should drop when the new thalamic connections stabilize.
I think you're right.
I was listening... when you were telling the nurses about the procedure.
I kept thinking that I wanted to thank you for what you were trying to do for me... and now I finally can. Thank you...
Did you move this?
Maybe I did. Maybe I didn't.
Leave him alone. It's where it's supposed to be, Patrick.
Hello, everyone.
Did you hear what she said? Did you hear that?
I don't think I've ever heard anything more beautiful in my life...
There's so much I want to say to all of you.
Why are you talking like that?
(scolding him for mentioning it) Quiet.
"There's so much I want to say to all of you."
Jack --
No. He's right. I can hear the way I sound.
Don't worry, it's only temporary. You just need practice.
Practice! Good idea. Listen to this, Sarina.
Doe-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-doe.
Doe-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-doe.
Are you tone deaf?
You're the one who's tone deaf. Doe-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-doe.
(a little better this time) Doe-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-doe.
Much better.
Doe-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti --
Doe-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti --
Doe-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti --
(capping it with a bass rumble) Doe.
Let's improvise... Lauren.
Motto Allegro.
It was amazing. Within a few minutes, Sarina's voice just took off. That kind of improvement usually takes weeks of speech therapy.
That is amazing, Julian...

I took her back to the Infirmary. She was exhausted, and I want to monitor her neural activity while she sleeps. I still can't get over the transformation. Yesterday, she was silent as a stone. Today, she's laughing and singing. You should've seen her, Miles.
How could I? I've been sitting here all night.
Is it Thursday?
Why I else would I be sitting here all night?
I'm sorry. I forgot.
It's all right.
Morn caught me up on how his seventeen brothers and sisters are doing. Did you know Fulp had another son?
No, really?
Hard to believe, isn't it? Well, I've got to push off. Early day tomorrow.
Sorry about the mixup, Miles.
Don't worry about it, Julian. I'm happy for her. For both of you.
-- fa-sol-la-ti-doe.
Sarina, what are you doing here? How'd you get in?
It wasn't hard. Your access code only has six digits.
Is something wrong?
I couldn't sleep.
The nurse would've given you something.
I don't want to sleep...
Why not?
What if... I wake up the way I was?
That's not going to happen.
That part of your life is over. From now on, everything's going to be different. Your future is full of possibilities.
Sarina... ?
Good morning.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Morning.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: You didn't account for the L-Two codon.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: What?
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: (handing him the PADD) That's why the virus mutated. You have to target the RNA transcriptor. Hungry?
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: The L-Two codon, of course. Why didn't I see that?
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Sarina, you're amazing. I've been working on this for months.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: (handing him his coffee) You would've seen it sooner or later.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I don't know about that. (studying her with new appreciation) Thank you.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I'm glad I could do something for you -- you've done so much for me.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Infirmary to Doctor Bashir.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Go ahead.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: You're needed in surgery, sir.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: On my way.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I'm probably going to be tied up for a few hours. What would you like to do in the meantime?
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: How about a tour of the station? I could ask Ezri to show you around.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: That's all right. I think I'll go see Jack and the others.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: All right. I'll send someone to take you to the Cargo Bay. When I'm out of surgery, I'll join you there.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Wait.
scene: 30   INT. BASHIR'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: The fact is that the universe is going to stop expanding and collapse in on itself. We've got to do something before it's too late.
How much time do we have left?
Sixty trillion years, seventy at the most.
Oh, no.
Isn't Nog handsome?
What are you doing? We're running out of time!
Sarina, thank God! No one else around here listens to me.
What is it, Jack? What's wrong?
(indicating the Okudagram) There's too much matter... the universe is too heavy for its own good.
So lighten the load...
Yes. Exactly. We have to find some way to decrease the mass...
Of the entire universe?
That's the whole point.
Is that possible?
That's what we're trying to figure out, Sarina.
What if we found a way to manipulate subspace... ?
(picking up her thought) Change the cosmological constant.
That would do the trick.
You can't change the cosmological constant.
(with elaborate patience) You know something, Sarina? We're trying to save existence as we know it, and all you can do is criticize.
I'm sorry...
Thank you. Now, where were we?
Doctor!
Glad you're here.
Is she all right?
You all right, Sarina? She's fine. You have to talk to Starfleet for us. We need subspace field generators, lots of them.
(crossing toward Sarina) Can we talk about it later?
Later? There's not going to be a later!
Sarina... ?
Hi...
Is something wrong?
No... (casting a glance toward the others) They're used to me being quiet... it's easier this way...
Some of my friends are getting together tonight at Quark's. I thought you might want to come along.
Me?
Would you like to?
What time should we be ready?
We're not invited, Jack. Just her.
Figures.
That doesn't seem fair...
It's all right. We have work to do, anyway. Come on, Sarina. Let's get you dressed.
Come on out.
Am I good, or am I good?
Look at all the people...
There they are.
I didn't remember her being so...
Beautiful?
Everyone, Sarina. Sarina, everyone.
Miles.
I remember you. You're Julian's best friend.
We get on all right...
For the most part...
Why are you pretending that it's not true?
Because they're men.
And men have trouble expressing their feelings.
You don't.
Are you kidding? Odo never talks about his feelings.
He took your hand.
He's showing you his feelings.
Thank you.
Julian, show me how much you love me -- go get us another round.

I liked your friends. All of them. If I had to find someone to replace Atlas and hold up the world, it'd be Miles -- he'd do it with a smile, too. And Kira -- she never doubts herself, which is what Odo finds so fascinating because he doubts everything but her.
(fascinated by her take on them) What about Ezri?
The day she realizes that she's more than just the sum of her parts, she's really going to be something.
I can't believe you saw all that just by spending a few hours with them. I'm going to have to start putting on my poker face.
Too late. You've already given yourself away.
Is that right? And how would you describe me?
Compassionate. Brilliant. Lonely.
Well, two out of three ain't bad.
Which two?
That would be telling.
I'm glad you liked my friends, they liked you, too.
I felt so comfortable around them. I didn't have to worry that someone was going to throw a tantrum, or break into tears all of a sudden.
They usually only do that at staff meetings.

Jack is always talking about how we're better than "normal" people; he says that's why they keep us "locked up." But he's wrong. (saddened by the thought) He couldn't get by in the real world, he'd get himself into too much trouble. So would Lauren and Patrick.
That's why the Institute's the best place for them. In fact, Doctor Loews wants me to get them back there as soon as possible.
I'm not going with them, am I?
It's not where you belong. Not anymore.
Do they know?
Not yet.
They've been like a family to me for as long as I can remember... as difficult as they can be sometimes, I'm going to miss them. We had our own little world, just the four of us.
So what's a genetically enhanced girl supposed to do when she wakes up from a long sleep? Point to one of those little specks of light out there, pack her bag, and go make a life for herself?
Why does she have to go anywhere?
She's wonderful, Miles. I've never met anyone like her. She's brilliant, sweet -- everything's new to her.
Being with her makes me appreciate things I usually take for granted.
(sticking his finger in the mug) Like hot coffee.
Yes, coffee. Or music, or the way the stars shine.
(muttering as he works) What's wrong with this thing...
Are you listening to me?
Yes. Coffee, music, stars.
Well, don't you have anything to say?
As a matter of fact, I do. I haven't seen you like this in a long time, and I'm really happy for you. But don't you think this is all happening a little fast?
We're genetically enhanced -- we do everything fast.
But, Julian, she's your patient.
Not anymore. I asked Doctor Girani to take over her care.
Miles, I don't think you understand what this means to me.

All these years I've had to hide the fact that my DNA had been resequenced. I'd hear people talk about the genetically engineered, saying they were all misfits. I used to fantasize about meeting someone like me -- someone who was able to live a normal life. But it never happened. Until Sarina. Don't you see? She's the woman I've been waiting for all my life.
Sarina isn't going back to the Institute with you.
She's not?
She's going to stay here.
Really? How nice for you.
You have no right to do this! No right!
I know you're going to miss her, but this is what's best for Sarina.
We didn't help you just so you could take her away from us!
Stop thinking about yourself for a second and start thinking about her. Face it, Jack. She doesn't belong with you anymore.
Why? Because we're not normal? Because we're crazy?
Jack...
Couldn't you make us normal? Like you did for Sarina? Then we could all stay together.
Go ahead, Julian. Tell him. There's nothing you can do for us. We're too far gone.
Who wants to be normal anyway? We're better than they are. You don't see any of them trying to keep the universe from collapsing, do you?
Let's get back to work.
I'm afraid they took it rather hard...
I should go talk to them.
In the morning. Give them a little time to get used to the idea.
Come on, I know just the thing to cheer you up.
Dabo!
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: She's unbelievable...
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Tell them how you do it.
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Go on.
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: (placing another bet) It has to do with a series of binomial equations and probability factors...
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Explain how you track the dependent variables.
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: It's really not that interesting.
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Dabo!
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Well, hasn't this been fun! Why not have a seat, and top off the evening with a lovely bottle of springwine?
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Should we?
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: He's just trying to get you to stop playing so he won't lose any more money.
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Did I mention the wine was on the house?
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Julian, let's sit down.
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: But she's winning.
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: I've played enough.
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Sarina?
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: This way.
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Julian, would you mind if we left?
scene: 47   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DABO WHEEL

quote: I'm sorry. I thought you were having a good time.
I was. But there was so much commotion. Maybe I'm just tired.
(stopping at her door) Tell you what, tomorrow night we'll have a nice quiet dinner in my quarters.
I've got a week's leave coming up. I thought we could go to Risa together -- get away from all the distractions around here and have some time alone.
All right.
Well, I'll let you get some rest.
Computer, music. Something... romantic.
Sarina Douglas is presently in her quarters on Level Twelve.
Sarina, it's me.
Computer, override door locks. Authorization Bashir Delta-Five- Seven-Alpha.
I've been waiting in my quarters for you.
Is something wrong?
Sarina?
Sarina.
Apparently the thalamic pathways I generated are still functional, but Doctor Girani's not detecting much neural activity in them.
Do you have any idea what's wrong?
Not a clue. She's just... slipping away again. And there's nothing I can do except wait, and hope she pulls out of it.
Sarina... ?
Everything's going to be all right. Don't be afraid.
I'm not going to give up on you. Ever.
I don't know what's wrong with her. I need your help.
Why should we help you? You just want to steal her away from us.

Look at her. Do you really want her to spend the rest of her life like this? I've been trying to find a way to reach her, but I can't. Maybe there isn't one. All I'm asking is that you try. The three of you know her better than anyone else. Please, I don't want to lose her.
All right, Julian. Leave her here with us for a while. We'll see what we can do.
Are you sure?
I'm sure.
We've got to tell him.
Why? This way we can all stay together.
Let's go.
This way.
That way.
(pointing back the way they came) I think we passed it.
Can I help you?
That's a stupid question.
Yes, come in.
We've got to talk to you.
About Sarina?
Tell him.
She can still talk, it's just that she's afraid to.
I don't understand. What's she afraid of?
We don't know.
But it has something to do with you.
Stay here. I'm going to go talk to her.
Sarina, please... talk to me. I know you can.
What's wrong? Tell me. Don't be afraid. Is it me? Because if it is, I'll do whatever it takes to make it right.
I love you. I want us to be together.
Sarina, do you love me... ?
I don't know...
I don't even understand what love is...
I don't understand anything...
Sarina...
What am I supposed to do... what am I supposed to feel... ? Tell me. I want to make you happy. I owe you everything.
No... you don't owe me anything...
(hating herself for her failure) I'm sorry... I wish I could be the woman you want me to be...
Morning.
Is she gone?
Her transport leaves in a few minutes.
What about the others?
They left for the Institute this morning.
I hear you arranged a position for Sarina at the Corgal Research Center.
An internship. She's going to work under one of the scientists there, live with his family.
You okay?

How could I have been so blind, Miles? What was I thinking trying to move things along so fast? She needed time, and I didn't give it to her. I came this close to driving her back inside herself. I'm supposed to be a doctor. I'm supposed to put my patient's needs above my own.
You didn't want to be lonely anymore... nobody does.
Look, I've got to get to work. Do you want to come over for dinner tonight? Keiko's making tempura.
Thanks, anyway.
So here you are... on your way to one of those little specks of light out there.
I guess that's what a genetically enhanced girl should do when she wakes up from her sleep... go make a life for herself.
I'm going to miss you...
(hoarse with emotion) I'm going to miss you.
You won't forget me?
Forget you? Never.
All passengers bound for Corgal Two should board at this time.
Well, I'd better go.
Commander Worf... I hope you'll accept my deepest sympathies regarding the approaching demise of the Klingon Empire.
The Klingon Empire will outlive the Dominion by many centuries.
Your loyalty to a hopeless cause is admirable. (turning his attention to Ezri) You must be Ezri Dax. My predecessors -- Weyoun Four and Five -- had a high regard for your predecessor, Jadzia.
I assure you, the feeling wasn't mutual.
How unfortunate. After all, you and I have so much in common. We're both merely individual links in a long chain.
And that's where any similarity ends...
I hoped we could have an amicable relationship. (to a Jem'Hadar soldier)
Secure the prisoners below. And make sure they share a cell. They may wish to physically comfort each other during the long trip back to Cardassia.
I find inter-species mating rituals fascinating to watch. Don't you?
Interesting device.
I'm so sorry. Where are my manners? Allow me to introduce Legate Damar, head of the Cardassian Union. Thot Gor.
What did he say?
He says you need to get your universal translator adjusted.
I would've -- if I had known we were meeting with the Breen.
It is a distinct pleasure to finally meet you.
Thank you. If our face-to-face talks are as productive as our subspace communications have been, I'm sure we'll sign the treaty documents within a few days.
I haven't even seen this treaty.
We'll discuss it later.

This is a great day. The alliance between the Breen Confederacy and the Dominion will end the destructive war that has torn this quadrant apart for so long. With the Breen at our side, the Federation will not be able to stand against us. They'll be erased from the face of the galaxy...
This is outrageous! Have you read this treaty?
Parts of it.
There's a reference to "territorial concessions" that Cardassia will make to the Breen. But it doesn't say what those concessions are.

Oh, you needn't worry about that. They've all been itemized in a secret protocol between the Dominion and the Breen. All you're required to do is sign the document as the acknowledged leader of the Cardassian Union.
I want to see this protocol.
It wouldn't be much of a secret then, would it?
You expect me to agree to territorial concessions when I don't even know what they are?
Damar, you're missing the point. We need the Breen to win this war. When it's over, there will be more than enough territories available to compensate Cardassia for the loss of a few minor planets.
There are no "minor" planets in the Cardassian Union --
You know what I think you should do? Talk to Thot Gor. Express your concerns. He's very reasonable and quite personable once you get to know him.
I don't trust him or his people. The Founders should never have agreed to give away Cardassian territory without my consent!
I'm sorry, I think I misunderstood you. It sounded as if you were implying that Cardassian territory did not belong to the Founders. Surely that's not what you meant.
No. Of course not.
Good. I look forward to receiving the signed documents from you within the hour.
Is there something else?
The Klingons have attacked Septimus Three.
I'm aware of that.
Are you also aware that they've landed fifteen divisions? The Cardassian troops will not survive without reinforcements.
I assure you that the Septimus Three situation will be dealt with. We won't allow your brave soldiers to perish in vain. You have my word.
Septimus Three will fall within the week! The Cardassian Eleventh Order is a reserve unit -- old men and walking wounded. They don't stand a chance.
I think you're right.
But enough about the war with the Dominion. I want to hear about the war at home. You just married that freighter captain, didn't you?
Yes...

Then war has broken out, whether you know it or not. A long, grueling, intoxicating war. I remember the day my beloved Sirella first moved into my home. I had a pet targ. Had him since I was a boy. A filthy, mangy beast -- but in his bony breast beat the heart of a warrior. Of course, Sirella loathed him. To make a long story short, while supervising the unloading of her bags, Sirella "accidently" left the front door open.
My faithful targ, ever-ready to follow the call of the wild, tottered outside on his frail legs and disappeared into the forest. I never laid eyes on him again.
Lady Sirella draws first blood.

You see my point. Don't get me wrong, I would not trade Sirella for all the targs on Kronos... And over the course of our marriage I've won more than my fair share of the battles between us. But in the end, I know she will win the war.
I'll keep that in mind.
(inspecting the plate) You ate all the milaberries...
Have Solbor bring us more.
And give him another chance to frown disapprovingly?
The good Ranjen doesn't much care for me, does he?
You'd think he'd be pleased to see his Kai so happy.
Are you happy, Adami?
More than I've ever been in my life...
The Prophets are smiling on us, Anjohl. They've not only brought us together, they've given us a great task -- the Restoration of Bajor.
Our world will be reborn. And you will be its leader.
It's a sacred responsibility...
I pray I have the strength to do what the Prophets are asking of me...
I'll be at your side. We won't fail them.
But the Restoration will not come without a struggle. There will be those who'll stand in our way.
No one can be allowed to interfere with the will of the Prophets...
Not even those who claim to speak in their name.
The Emissary...
In your vision, the Prophets said he'd faltered.
I can only hope he doesn't choose to oppose them. Their love is strong, but so is their wrath...
I hate to say it... but this is doing wonders for my back.
I doubt that was the intent of our captors.
Probably not...
We must get back to the station and warn Starfleet about the Breen...
You're right. There's just a few problems. We're on a Jem'Hadar ship... hanging upside down... heading in the wrong direction... and...
And what?
I think I'm getting spacesick...
Welcome home, Mrs. Sisko.
Thank you, Mr. Sisko.
How was the cargo run?

Interesting. It seems my Bajoran crewmembers have decided that serving under the wife of the Emissary is a little different than serving under his girlfriend. I've known some of those people for ten years or more and suddenly they're asking me for advice about their children, their husbands, their wives... their spiritual relationship with the Prophets...
Welcome to the club. Which reminds me... every spring, the Emissary holds a little ceremony to bless the women on the station who want to become mothers someday...
What does that have to do with me?
There's been a request made -- several, in fact -- that the Emissary's new wife perform the ceremony this year. This week, actually...
No.
Kas...
No. I've got to draw the line somewhere. I married you -- I didn't convert. And I'm not going to start acting like I suddenly believe in the Prophets.
I don't want you to do anything you're uncomfortable with.
Good. Then it's settled. I'm going to take a sonic shower.
Take your time. Dinner won't be ready for another fifteen minutes.
(to himself, philosophical) And so the battle begins...
Let me try.
No. You lack the necessary strength.
And your fingers are too fat. Now move over --
Ow!
Be quiet.
Are you hurt?
Yes, I'm hurt. You cut my finger and made me hit my head!
It was an accident.
I still don't understand how getting a pin out of that bunk is going to help us escape.
If you would stop interfering and allow me to remove the pin, I will show you. Now let me look at your head.
No, thanks. The last time you touched me, things got a little out of control.
You are right about that. I was seduced and betrayed.
Seduced? I seduced you?
At least we agree on that point.
We do not!
You desired a physical relationship with me from the start. That much was obvious.
You have the biggest ego of any man I've ever known.
Considering how many men you've known, that is quite a statement.
Am I supposed to be embarrassed that Jadzia had a few lovers before you?
A few?
You're right. It was more than a few. It was dozens. Hundreds. In fact, I don't think there was anyone aboard D.S. Nine who wasn't her lover!
Let me take this opportunity to welcome you both to Cardassia Prime. I trust you've been well- cared for so far?

I've been looking over the information you supplied to the Breen during your interrogation, and the results are a bit confusing -- as mental probes so often are... I was wondering if you wouldn't mind sifting through the data and clarifying certain issues for us...
You can't be serious.
I'm always serious. You see, if you don't do as I ask, I'll have to hand you over to Legate Damar... ... and you know how ruthless Cardassians can be.
"It is my duty to inform you that you are to be turned over to a Cardassian Tribunal to stand trial as war criminals."
War criminals? What are the charges?
It is not necessary for you to know that.
However... if you decide to help us in our search for a quick end to this miserable war, your sentence will be reduced to life imprisonment.
You want to end the war? Why don't you convince the Founders to surrender.
You know, my dear... it would be a shame if you were to die without the good Doctor Bashir knowing how you felt about him.
Wait!
Overconfident. The hallmark of the Weyouns. Maybe the Founders should eliminate that from your genetic recipe next time.
You know they'll just make another copy of him. You should've killed me; there's only one Damar.
I'll keep that in mind.
I'm sure you will. Consider his offer, Klingon. You die in two days. (to Guards, re:
Who are you?
What do you mean?
I mean, who are you, Anjohl Tennan? I want to know everything -- about your family, your childhood...
It would bore you...
Not at all. What might seem trivial to you matters a great deal to me. I need to know more about this guide the Prophets have sent me... this simple farmer... this man who shares my bed...
We are of Bajor.
We await the Restoration.
I am ready. I have met the Guide. You need only tell me what to do. I give myself to the Prophets in all things.
She does not understand.
She is fearful.
There is no other path. She is the chosen one. She must embrace us.
I will. I swear it! Give me a chance -- please.
Give us your allegiance Kai Winn Adami...
Restore us to our rightful place in the Celestial Temple...
Reject the false Prophets...
Walk our path... and embrace your own destiny.
Feel our love... the love... of the Pah-Wraiths...
No... NO!!!
What is it?
What happened?
They... they came to me... a vision.
Blessed be the Prophets...
No! They weren't the Prophets. They were...
They were... what?
Pah-wraiths.
Find Solbor. Have him go to the Shrine and bring me the Orb.
I must bare my soul to the Prophets and beg their forgiveness...
Eminence, are you sure that's wise? What do the Prophets --
Go! Bring me the Orb!
Well. Hello.
I'm glad you find the death of my predecessor so amusing.
You misjudge me. I miss him deeply. Here -- let's drink to Weyoun Seven.
When will the prisoners be executed?
When their trial is completed. The legal protocols must be observed.
When?
The execution is scheduled for tomorrow afternoon. Fourteen hundred hours.
Have they signed the confessions?
No. Maybe you should talk to Worf again.
Ah. Welcome to our command center.
Of course. Go right ahead.
Absolutely not! That database is classified --
What Legate Damar means to say is that the entire database is open to you. Feel free to examine it at your leisure.
You surely don't mean that.
On the contrary, I'm quite sincere.
They don't need to know everything about our military operations in order to help us.
The decision was made by the Founder herself. The Founder has also decided that from now on your military recommendations should be submitted to Thot Gor, who will pass them on to her.
I will not!
I trust that was simply an unguarded emotional outburst, so I will ignore it. This time.
Make plans to do exactly as the Founder has instructed or you can schedule an execution for yourself as well.
Ready.
scene: 21   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - CLOSE ON WALL PANEL

quote: Go! Leave me!
Shut up.
You never listen...
Look who's talking.

... and I've always wanted to see the mountains of Andoria. I know there's no way we're going to get away before the war's over, but after that -- I'm taking my husband on a honeymoon even if I have to kidnap him to do it.
I'll help tie him up if that's what it takes.
Koganka pudding.
I didn't order this.
Compliments of Ranjen Surfan and his wife. It's traditional or something.
Enjoy.
Better get used to it.

(with a rueful smile) Just call me Mrs. Emissary... Do you know I've had complete strangers stop me on the Promenade and ask me to ask the Prophets to bless their children, their crops, their homes...
It must be a little overwhelming.
Ridiculous is what it is.
I don't talk to the Prophets -- I don't even believe in the Prophets.
Not that there's anything wrong with believing in the Prophets...
(smiling, no offense taken) It's all right
It's just that I have my own set of beliefs. Beliefs that I was brought up with. That's why I don't feel right about what Ben is asking me to do.
My father was never a religious man, but once he got married, he attended services every day because it was important to my mother.
That's very sweet... I guess I'm just afraid that if I do this for Ben -- if I start down that road -- where will it all end? I don't want to lose sight of the things I believe in.
I can understand that.
I mean, didn't it bother your father to do something he didn't believe in just because your mother did?
I asked him that once. You know what he told me? That that was as good a definition of marriage as he'd ever heard.
The Bajoran couple at table four.
I love Ben... and I want to make him happy. But how much Koganka can I eat?
Do you have to do that?
I do it every day at this time.
I know. But it's sort of... morbid.
Morbid? That implies she's not coming back.
I'm not trying to imply anything of the kind.
One of these days Ezri's going to come walking through those doors again and this drink is going to be sitting right here waiting for her when she does.
Well, in the meantime, all you're doing is reminding us that she's missing.
No one's forcing you to sit here.
It was the Badlands...
What?
What?
You said something about the Badlands.
Did I? I was just thinking that... if Worf's escape pod hadn't drifted into the Badlands, the Defiant would've found him and Ezri never would've had to go out looking for him.
I never thought I'd hear myself say this... but I wish the Defiant had found that lumbering Klingon oaf.
We can't do anything to change what's happened, so let's just... hope for the best.
I was just starting to...
"Starting to" what... ?
I don't know. But there was something about her... something that made me... happy. She was an old soul and yet she was young at heart. I don't even know what I'm saying.
Where is he?
He'll be here any moment. He said there were certain security precautions that had to be observed before the Orb could be removed from the Shrine. May I ask what you're planning to--
No you may not. This is far beyond your ability to comprehend, Anjohl.
Come in.
The Orb of Prophecy...
Place it on the table and then go.
How may I serve you?
You are not required here. Thank you.
There's nothing to fear.
Of course not. I am the Kai. The Prophets will make everything clear to me.
Something's wrong
What?
There's nothing. The Prophets show me nothing. They won't speak to me...
They've forsaken me... because I've been in communion with the evil ones...
Adami... this may be hard for you to hear... but you must listen.
There's something I've hidden from you. I didn't come here by chance. I had a vision... the true gods of Bajor came to me and asked me to serve them.
The "true gods"... ?
The Pah-wraiths. They led me to you.
No...
They're not evil. They care about Bajor.
No...
They want to make it strong.
HERETIC!
Listen to me!
GET AWAY!!
Enough! The Prophets have done nothing for you. During the Occupation, they turned their backs and let our people suffer.
Let me go!
You've sacrificed everything for them, and how have they rewarded you? By choosing an alien to be their Emissary. They've rejected you at every turn. Even now they won't speak to you.
(calling over her shoulder) Solbor!
The Pah-wraiths will give you everything you've ever dreamed of -- power, the adoration of your people. In spite of all your protestations of humility, that's what you've always wanted. Admit it.
Stop pretending to be something that you're not. Take what they're offering you.
Get out.
So be it. Go crawling back to your Prophets. Beg their forgiveness. Live the rest of your life in Sisko's shadow.
I'll do anything you ask... you need only give the word.
Have you nothing to say to me? Am I so offensive to your eyes that I no longer exist to you?
There must be something I can do to prove that I'm still worthy of your love.
Go ahead.
This is Kai Winn.
I need to speak with you. Could you come to my quarters?
Of course.
Colonel Kira to see you, eminence.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Come in, child. Thank you for seeing me at such a late hour.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: What can I do for you?
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: I've often sensed that you don't approve of how I've conducted myself as Kai -- that you believe I've put my own political interests ahead of our people's spiritual well-being.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: I wish I could say I disagreed with that assessment...
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: I've strayed from the path the Prophets laid down for me...
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Eminence...
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: You don't know... you don't know...
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Eminence, when you told me that the Prophets had spoken to you, I prayed that it would open your heart. That it would change you --
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: I want to change -- I'd do anything to earn their forgiveness. But I'm afraid it's too late --
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: It's never too late. Even the worst of us can be redeemed.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: How?
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: I'm not a Vedek, but it seems to me that you have to set aside the things that led you astray -- ambition, jealousy...
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: (desperate to believe) Yes, I've given in to the temptations of power.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Then turn away from temptation --
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Yes --
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Give yourself over to the Prophets.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: I'll do whatever it takes to make myself worthy in their eyes.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: (moved by her remorse) Everything will change once you step down as Kai, you'll see.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Step down?
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: I don't understand. Why would I do that? Bajor needs me.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: (I thought we agreed) Eminence, being in power is what led you down the wrong path.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: But I'm resolved to change.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Don't you see? Once I've regained the Prophets' trust, I'll be better able to serve them if I remain Kai.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: If the Prophets wanted me to step down, surely they would have told me so.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: They don't always use words to make their wishes known. Sometimes they speak to us by touching our hearts. And only you would know if they've done that.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Bajor needs me...
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Good night, eminence.
scene: 31A  INT. KAI WINN'S QUARTERS - LIVING ROOM

quote: Damar. There you are. I want you to hear this. Thot Gor had an interesting observation regarding our forces along the Romulan border. In his view, we have failed to take advantage of several weaknesses in their defenses.
Is that so.
For instance, their colony in the Unroth System is ripe for attack. Their long-range sensor array is being repaired and...
Septimus Three has fallen!
Excuse me?
Septimus Three -- an entire Cardassian Order has been wiped out! Five hundred thousand men!
Oh, yes. A great tragedy.
You promised reinforcements!
I promised no such thing. I said the situation would be dealt with and it was.
By leaving them to be slaughtered by the Klingons?

If you will calm down and listen, I'll explain. The sacrifice made by the Eleventh Order was not in vain. They forced the Klingons to commit valuable troops and resources to capture a strategically worthless planet.
I'm glad you agree.
Well, I don't! You condemned a half million loyal Cardassians --
If they were truly loyal, then they died willingly for the Dominion. There can be no greater sacrifice.
And how many more of these sacrifices will my people be asked to make?
Your people? We are all one with the Dominion. Vorta, Cardassian, Jem'Hadar, now Breen -- we all serve the Founders and we'll all make whatever sacrifices they deem necessary.
Thot Gor, would you mind reiterating your plans for the Unroth System? I seem to have lost my train of thought.
Yes, I know. It's become increasingly difficult to get a full day's work out of him.

The Dax symbiont has lived for over three hundred years. Experienced eight lifetimes. And now it's all going to end... with an execution on Cardassia. Ezri Tigan's contribution to the Dax legacy... will be to end it.
There is no honor in self-pity.

You know Worf, I've had just about enough of your little Klingon aphorisms. The only reason I came on this mission was to save your miserable life, so the least you can do is stop acting like a self-righteous targ.
Your motives for finding me were not honorable.
Do you really think I disobeyed orders, and risked my life so I could seduce you? I hate to burst your bubble Worf, but it wasn't that good.
Always the barb, always the joke.
There was a time when you thought my sense of humor was one of my more endearing qualities.
No! That was Jadzia! Not you!
Are you angry at me because of something I've done or because I'm not Jadzia?
Let's cut right to the heart of the matter. Do you really love me -- me? Ezri?
You are trying to turn this around and make it about me...
Answer the question. Do you love me?
I made my feelings clear back on Goralis Three.

What is it, Worf? Could it be that you're feeling guilty? That you don't have the same feelings for me that you had for Jadzia? If that's true, maybe we both made a mistake back on Goralis. So maybe we both should be forgiven.
This night would be better spent preparing ourselves for the next life, rather than rehashing the mistakes of this one.
First of all, let me welcome all of you to my home. Now, I know that many of you had requested that my wife conduct today's ceremony, but--
Sorry I'm late.
You owe me one.
I won't forget.
All right, let's see a show of hands -- who wants boys?
You're up early today.
I didn't get much sleep.
Something wrong?
It's about Ezri. And you.
I'm not sure I'm following...
If she does come back -- and I hope to god she does -- I don't want to see you hurt her.
Hurt her?
I know you'd never do it intentionally.
Wait a minute. You make it sound like we're involved.
Would you like to be?
Are you asking my intentions, old boy?
I suppose I am.
She's not your daughter, Miles.
Well, for some reason, I feel protective of her. Maybe it's because I spent time with her family, maybe it's because I know she's had a hard time adjusting to being joined.
Do you realize that, technically speaking, she's older than both of us combined?
Stop avoiding the question. Are you interested in her?
I suppose I am sort of...
She'd be furious if she knew that I was in here acting like her father, but what the hell. Treat her right, or you'll have to answer to me. Understood?
Yes, sir.
All right, then.
That was good practice.
For what?
For when Molly grows up.
Oh, God. Don't even say it.
You are right.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: What... ?
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: I said... you are right. I... do not love you as I loved Jadzia.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: There's no crime in that.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: I... dishonored myself. I know how often I use that word... perhaps too often. But in this case, it is... appropriate. From the moment I first saw you on the station, I knew that you were not Jadzia. And yet I also knew that a part of her was still alive within you. On Goralis, I allowed myself to see her... instead of you.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: I felt the same way. A part of me -- the part that was your wife -- wanted very much to be close to you.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: I realize that Jadzia saw... physical love very differently than I do. To her it could have many meanings... but to me it is a... deeply spiritual act. When I made love to you, my motives were not... spiritual. It was... an unworthy impulse.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: Worf, we're not gods or prophets. We're people. We make mistakes.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: There is... one other thing I want you to know. I honestly didn't realize how I felt about... Julian. I would've never hidden something like that from you.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: I believe you. And I bear no malice toward you... or Doctor Bashir.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: That's good to know.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: Friends?
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: Yes. And more.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: And more.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: It would appear that all we have left to do is... to be executed.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: Sounds like a lazy day to me.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: It's time.
scene: 38   INT. CARDASSIAN HOLDING CELL - ON EZRI

quote: There's a Cardassian patrol ship sitting in Launch Bay Three-A, two levels above us. Its computer has all the necessary information to get you past our security checkpoints.
Why are you doing this?
I want you to give a message to the Federation -- tell them that they have an ally on Cardassia.
Why should we trust you?
You can trust me or you can stay here and be executed.
I vote for option one.
Escaped! How could this have happened?
You were the one who put the Jem'Hadar in charge of the detention area.
Thank you for reminding me.
No, I assure you this is not typical of our security procedures.
The Founder... wishes to see me. She'll have to be told about this...
I'm sure she'll understand. But if she doesn't... I look forward to meeting Weyoun Nine.
Eminence, Anjohl is here. (hoping it's not true) He claims you called for him.
Send him in.
As you wish...
I remember the first time I saw the Gate to the Celestial Temple. I was on the Promenade. When it burst into view -- this whirlpool of color and light -- the people around me were in awe.

They were saying that they could feel the love of the Prophets washing over them. Do you know what I felt, Anjohl? Nothing. Absolutely nothing. But I smiled and pretended I did. Because it was expected of me. I've never admitted that to anyone.
I can understand why...

They've never spoken to me. Never offered me guidance. Never trusted me with the fruits of their wisdom. And now, I'm supposed to step down as Kai in order to be blessed by them? No. I've worked too hard, waited too long to give it all up now.
You shouldn't have to. Merciful gods don't ask their children to make such sacrifices.
The Prophets have turned their backs on me... after all I've done for them... all the pain I've endured for them...
They are not worthy of you, Adami.
I'm a patient woman. But I've run out of patience. I will no longer serve gods who give me nothing in return. (with steely resolve) I'm ready to walk the path the Pah-wraiths have laid out for me.
And I'll walk it with you.
No one will be able to stand against us...
Those who dare to try -- the Federation and its Vedek puppets, the false gods and their precious Emissary -- they'll all be swept aside, like dead leaves before an angry wind...
Captain's Personal Log: Stardate Five-one-seven... Five-one-seven... four?
Computer -- what day is it?
Thursday. Stardate 51721.3.
It's only been two weeks...

I need to talk about this. I have to justify what's happened... what I've done... at least to myself. I can't talk to anyone else... not even Dax. Maybe if I just lay it all out in my log, it'll finally make sense... and I'll see where it all went wrong... where I went wrong.
I suppose it all started two weeks ago when I was posting the weekly casualty list in the wardroom...
... every Friday morning, for the past three months, I've posted the official list of Starfleet personnel killed, wounded or missing in the war.

(continuing, over above action) It's become something of a grim ritual around here. Not a week goes by that someone doesn't find the name of a loved one, a friend or an acquaintance on that damned list. I've grown to hate Fridays.
Someone you knew?
Leslie Wong.
The skipper of the Cairo?
She was an instructor at the Academy when I was a sophomore.
Do you know what happened to the Cairo?
Just that they disappeared on patrol near the Romulan Neutral Zone. But I'll look into it.
Don't bother. I'm sure it's the same old story -- the Jem'Hadar crossed over the Romulan border and caught them off-guard. It's only about the hundredth time it's happened.
I can't believe the Romulans are allowing them to violate their territory so brazenly. How do they get away with it?
The Romulans have a treaty of non- aggression and friendship with the Dominion. In practical terms that means they're willing to turn a blind eye to almost anything in the name of "friendship."
It's an intolerable situation. We should cross the Neutral Zone and destroy the Dominion bases.
And risk war with the Romulans? No, thank you. We're losing enough good people as it is. The last thing we need is a war on two fronts.
What we need is to bring the Romulans into the war on our side. With the combined forces of the Federation, the Klingons and the Romulans we could finally go on the offensive.

That's the last thing the Romulans want. Think about it -- they're in the perfect position. They get to sit back and watch as their biggest rivals slug it out in a long, bloody war. No one's threatening their interests. Why should they risk their necks? There's simply no reason for them to get involved in our war. No reason at all...
That was the moment I made the decision. It was like I had stepped through a door and locked it behind me. I was going to bring the Romulans into the war.

I was absolutely sure it was the right decision -- that's the frightening part -- how right it seemed at the time. And now... now all I can do is learn to live with that decision. And I'll have to live with it for the rest of my life...
It's in their own best interest to join the war -- that's the key, that's the reason the Romulans will finally take action. Not to do us any favors, but to protect themselves from the Dominion.
Okay. Let's say I'm the Romulan Proconsol. From where I'm sitting, the Dominion isn't a threat to me. I have a nonaggression pact with them. They're my allies.
You're not going to put your faith in some piece of paper are you?
Not at all. I've been watching the Dominion very closely since the beginning of the war. And so far, they've kept their part of the bargain.
They're violating your territory almost every day -- what kind of an ally is that?
So they're crossing through my backyard to give the Federation a bloody nose. I can't say that makes me very sad.
You can't be naive enough to think the Dominion will stop with the Federation? When they're finished with us, they'll be coming after you.
That's speculation.

The Founders see it as their sacred duty to bring order to the galaxy. Their order. Do you think they'll sit idly by and let you keep your chaotic empire next to their perfect order? No. If you watch us go under, what you're really doing is writing your own death warrant.
You're asking me to start a war based on wild theories.
They're not theories, they're facts!
Prove it!
How?

That's your problem. But before I plunge my people into a conflict that'll kill millions of loyal Romulan citizens, I'll need something more concrete than the self-serving arguments of a Starfleet officer. I'll need proof of Dominion duplicity. Not more words, proof!
Not bad, old man. You'd have made a decent Romulan.
Thanks. But I prefer spots to pointed ears.

Okay you convinced me. They're going to need evidence... But, if there is evidence of a Dominion plan to attack Romulus, it's probably buried deep in the bowels of their headquarters on Cardassia Prime.
Not exactly the most accessible place in the galaxy.
Not for us, maybe. But there is someone on this station who specializes in gaining access to places he's not welcome.
I must say I'm flattered, Captain. I had no idea you held such a lofty opinion of me.
Your faith in my ability to retrieve classified information from my former homeland is most gratifying.
I'm happy that you're happy. Now, can you do it?

You know, I had assumed this meeting was about the modifications I suggested for your new dress uniform -- you have had an opportunity to look over my design, haven't you? The new piping along the collar, the exaggerated cut of the jacket hemline emphasizing the--
Mister Garak. Let's dispense with the usual repartee and concentrate on the issue at hand. Can you do the job or not?

No one wants to see the Dominion destroyed more than I do. But asking me to go to Cardassia Prime, penetrate one of the most heavily guarded facilities in the quadrant, steal top secret war plans and then return them safely to you is not just another "job." It's more like a suicide mission and that is well outside my field of expertise.
I didn't say you had to go there yourself. I have to believe that a man like you still has a few contacts back home. A colleague from the Obsidian Order...
... an old friend... a reliable informant... someone who might owe you a favor.
Perhaps...
Well, then. I'd say it's time to call in a favor.

It would mean calling in all my favors, captain. To do what you're asking would use up every resource I have left on Cardassia. And it may be a very messy, very bloody business. Are you prepared for that?

I posted my fourteenth casualty list this morning. I'm already involved in a very messy, very bloody business. And the only way I can see to end it is to bring the Romulans into the war. I'm prepared to do whatever it takes to accomplish that goal, but I can't do it alone. I need help. Now, are you in or out?
I'm in.
My father used to say that the road to hell is paved with good intentions.
I laid the first stone right there. I'd committed myself. I'd pay any price, go to any lengths, because my cause was righteous. My... intentions were good. In the beginning, that seemed like enough.
If there's one thing I've learned over the years, it's that bad news invariably comes in the middle of the night.
Kira to Captain Sisko.
Go ahead, major.
We just received a priority-one communication from Starfleet Command. The Dominion has invaded Betazed.
From the initial reports, it seems that the invasion force must have come from somewhere in the Calandra Sector.
Did Starfleet Intelligence know anything about a buildup in that Sector?
No. They believed Calandra was too far from Dominion supply lines to be a threat.

There's plenty of blame to go around. The Tenth Fleet was supposed to be protecting Betazed and its outlying colonies, but they were caught out of position on a training exercise. What's worse, Betazed's own defense systems are obsolete and undermanned. The planet was theirs in less than ten hours.
With Betazed in the hands of the Jem'Hadar, the Dominion's in a position to threaten Vulcan... Andor... Tellar... Alpha Centauri...
If we ever needed a new ally... it's right now.
It's been three days, Garak. Have you made any progress?
Well... I suppose that depends on how you look at it.
How I look at it is that Betazed has just fallen to the Dominion and we need to get this operation underway.

I share your desire for swift action, captain. In fact, after our last conversation, I made a few discreet inquiries among my former associates still living on Cardassia. As I anticipated, they shared my loathing for the current government and were more than willing to take on an assignment aimed at its destruction.
That sounds like progress to me.
Doesn't it? Unfortunately... they're all dead now.
What?
Yes. All killed within one day of speaking with me. I suppose that's a testament to the effectiveness of Dominion security. One should admire such... efficiency.
I'm sorry.
I hope you're not giving up that easily.
After all, the stakes are much higher than a few dead operatives. The fate of the entire quadrant hangs in the balance -- or at least that's the case you made to me.
Do you have another plan?
As a matter of fact, I do. But I suspect that you won't like it.
Try me.
If you want to guarantee that we obtain evidence of a Dominion plan to attack the Romulans... I suggest we manufacture that evidence ourselves.

Maybe I should have put a stop to it right there. Said, "Thank you, very much for your input, Mister Garak, I'll take your suggestion under advisement," and then gone back to my office and forgotten about the whole thing. But I didn't. Because in my heart, I knew what he was saying made sense.
I'm listening.
His name is Vreenak. He's been a key member of the Romulan Senate for the past fourteen years.
He's Secretary of the War Plans Council, Vice-Chairman of the Tal Shiar, and one of the most trusted advisors to Proconsul Neral.
He's also the man who negotiated the non-aggression pact with the Dominion.

Since you're familiar with him, I'll skip the rest of his biography. What's important is that he continues to be one of the most ardently pro-Dominion voices in the Senate. If we can convince him that the Dominion is a threat, the rest of the Senate will follow.
Okay. How?

Ten days from now, Senator Vreenak will be making a trip to Soukara for a diplomatic meeting with Weyoun. I'm certain he could be persuaded to make a secret detour to D.S. Nine if he were invited by one Captain Benjamin Sisko.
How do you know Vreenak's visiting Soukara?

There are some things I'd rather not discuss. May I continue? When the Senator arrives, you will show him a holographic recording of a secret meeting held at the highest levels of the Dominion in which the planned invasion of Romulus is being discussed. You will tell the Senator that this information was obtained through various covert means at great cost to the Federation -- "at least ten good men lost their lives bringing it across the lines" -- that sort of thing. He will immediately suspect that it's a forgery, but you will assure him that such a thing would be impossible. "You see Senator, this is an official Cardassian transcript. It was recorded on a one-time optolythic data-rod used for official record-keeping. These rods are manufactured only as needed on Cardassia Prime. Information can only be transcribed on them once, and then cannot be altered."
He'll want to examine it.
Of course. And he'll discover to his amazement, that it's completely genuine. At least, so it will appear.
And in reality... ?

You will have handed him a genuine optolythic data-rod, but it will contain one of the most perfect forgeries ever fashioned. I'm still working on obtaining the data-rod, but I have located the man who will create the holo- recording.
You realize, I can't authorize something like this on my own. I'll have to clear it with Starfleet Command.
Of course. But I suspect that with the fall of Betazed they'll be ready to do whatever it takes to bring the Romulans into the war.
I'll let you know.
One last thing, captain. The man we need to forge the holo-program is currently sitting in a Klingon prison awaiting execution.
To save time and incidentally his life, I thought that perhaps you could contact Chancellor Gowron today and arrange a pardon.
What's his name?
Grathon Tolar.
I can't tell you how grateful I am, captain. The Klingons were going to execute me tomorrow. Of course, they say that every day -- one of the little games they like to play.
You do understand the terms of your parole?

Oh, yes. I have to promise to stay away from the Klingon Empire. That'll be tough. And I have to create some kind of "special" holo-program for you. I can't wait. I've never worked for Starfleet before.
Let's be very clear about this -- you're not working for Starfleet. This entire matter is strictly off the record. As far as you're concerned, you're working for me.
Oh. Oh, I see. This is a personal matter. Something "special." For your eyes only. Something with... perhaps, five or six Orion slave girls and--
I suggest you go wait in your quarters. Mister Garak will provide you with all the information you need.
Garak's here?
That's right.
Oh. Well. That's different. I'll... go wait in my quarters.
Why I didn't listen to the voice in the back of my mind telling me not to believe a word he said, I'll never know.
But it didn't take long for me to come face to face with the fact that I'd made a mistake.
Odo to Captain Sisko.
Go ahead, Constable.
I'm sorry to disturb you, but do you know a man named Grathon Tolar?
Why do you ask?
Because he just tried to kill Quark.
What happened?

As I understand it, Mister Tolar over there came in about two hours ago and ordered a bottle of Whelan Bitters. Fifteen minutes later, he ordered a second bottle. Then a third. He was halfway through his fourth when he decided to dance with... ...M'Pella. She was otherwise engaged running the Dabo wheel at the time and declined his invitation. He decided to force the issue and there was a brief struggle before Quark, in an uncharacteristic display of chivalry, attempted to intervene. So Tolar stabbed him.
Normally, he'd be sitting in a holding cell, but he claimed that he was a friend of yours.
He's no friend of mine. But... he is working for me. It's an extremely sensitive matter involving Federation security. I can't afford to have any record of him being on the station.
I see. I'm certainly aware of the need for special security measures during wartime... but as a matter of law, if Quark chooses to press charges against Tolar, I have no choice but to make an arrest.
Let me speak to Quark.
How is he?
How do I look? I'm a man who just had a brush with death
He'll be fine. His ribs deflected the knife from his vital organs. The bleeding was superficial.
Superficial? Do you know how much this shirt cost?
Doctor, will you excuse us for a moment?
I'll check on you again tomorrow.
Do you intend to press charges?
You bet I do.
What would it take... to... convince you... otherwise?
Are you offering me... a bribe?
I knew it. I've always liked you, captain. I suspected that somewhere deep down in your heart of hearts there was a tiny bit of Ferengi just waiting to get out.
What's your price?
Well... let's start with replacing my clothes... and M'Pella's clothes.
All right.
I'm not finished. I think I should also be compensated for the loss of business I've suffered today, which I would calculate as no less than five bars of gold- pressed latinum.
Done.
I'm also having a problem with station security -- they're holding some cargo containers I've been waiting for because of some kind of... missing import license or something.
I'll handle it. Anything else?
No. I think we can call it a bribe. And thank you, captain. Thank you for restoring my faith in the ninety-eighth Rule of Acquisition: "Every man has his price."
He's dropped the charges.
Hmm. Let him go. If you'll excuse me...
Tolar is your responsibility. Keep him out of sight and under control or the next man needing medical attention will be you. Do you understand?
Completely.
Hello, Grathon.

Bribery and cover up -- those were new for me. That was my first moment of real doubt. I started to wonder if the whole thing was a mistake. Then I got back to my office and there was a new casualty list waiting for me. People are dying out there. Every day. Entire worlds are struggling for their freedom and here I am still worrying about the finer points of morality. I had to keep my eye on the ball. Winning the war, stopping the bloodshed -- those were the priorities.
So I pushed on. And every time another doubt appeared before me, I just found another way to shove it aside.
Mind if I join you?
Be my guest.
Ops.
Hold.
The less I'm seen parading through Ops the better.
I couldn't agree more.
You seem angry.
Who's watching Tolar?
I've locked him in his quarters. I've also left him with the distinct impression that if he attempts to force open the door, it may... explode.
I hope that's just an impression.
It's best not to dwell on such minutiae. In any case, we have far more important matters to discuss. I've located a gentleman willing to sell us a genuine optolythic data-rod.
How do you know it's genuine?
I trust the source, but rest assured I will confirm the rod's authenticity before I make payment -- which brings me to you.
How much does he want?
I'm afraid he's not interested in latinum. The gentleman in question has requested to be compensated with two hundred liters of bio-memetic gel.
What?
I don't know why, exactly. One would assume that it has something to do with genetic experimentation.
Offer him something else.
Believe me, I wouldn't be relaying this request if I thought he'd accept anything else.
Bio-memetic gel is strictly controlled by the Federation and not for sale at any price. Find someone else willing to sell us a rod.

I was not exaggerating when I told you about the near-impossibility of obtaining a genuine Cardassian data-rod. It's something of a minor miracle that I've found one source, I'm virtually certain that I'll never find another. I'm afraid we either have to give him what he wants or forget the whole enterprise.
Then let's forget it. Ops.
Hold.
Two hundred liters is out of the question. There isn't that much gel in this entire sector.
I believe... the quantity is open to negotiation.
Ops.

Captain... bio-memetic gel is an extremely dangerous compound. I can't release it without some idea of where it's going. In the wrong hands, it could be used to develop biogenic weapons, or for illegal replication experiments or organo- explosives or--

Perhaps I didn't make myself clear, Doctor. This isn't a request, it's an order. You will package eighty-five liters of bio- memetic gel for interstellar transport and then deliver it to Cargo Bay Three, is that understood?
Yes, sir. But I'd like that order in writing. Sir.
I thought you might.
You should know that I'll note this in my log and file a protest with Starfleet Medical.
That's your right. But I want the gel by the end of the day. Dismissed.
The Founders have decided to implement Stage Two ahead of schedule.
The invasion of Romulus? It's too soon. We're engaged in heavy fighting all along the border with the Federation. The Klingons are preparing to go on the offensive and --

Fortunately, the Founders have better vision than you do. They can see the opportunities in front of us even when you cannot. Consider: the Romulans do not expect an attack from Cardassia. The bulk of the Romulan fleet is still deployed along the Neutral Zone with the Federation. The Founders estimate that we could be on Romulus itself in less than three weeks.
Three weeks? I heard the same kind of estimates before we attacked the Federation.
Those plans were ruined by the incompetency of your predecessor.
Gul Dukat is a great man.
Gul Dukat is a preening egotist and a fool. We offered him unchallenged control of the Alpha Quadrant and all he could think about was his daughter. Now... shall we get back to the business at hand?
That's it. Freeze program.
That's all the new material. The rest of the program plays out just as you saw before. What do you think?
It's better. They seem more real.
All I had to do was add a little petty bickering and mutual loathing.
So you're happy?
It's satisfactory.
You may record the program onto the data-rod now.
I've received a message from Senator Vreenak -- he's on his way.
Excellent.
Done. Who gets it?
